name: Public Service Rules (PSR)
description: Comprehensive rules governing appointments, promotions, discipline, retirement, and administration in the Nigerian Federal Civil Service

subcategories.name: Appointments, Promotions & Transfers
subcategories.description: Questions on appointment authority, recruitment, probation, transfers, postings, acting appointments and promotion rules from PSR 2021 (Chapters 2 & 3).

questions.question: Who has the authority to make appointments to posts graded GL.07–GL.17 in the Federal Public Service?
questions.explanation: PSR 020102 states that the Federal Civil Service Commission (FCSC) makes appointments to posts graded GL.07–GL.17. (PSR 020102).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a recognized category of appointment under the PSR?
questions.explanation: PSR 020202 lists trainees, probationable pensionable appointments, non-pensionable contract, acting and special appointments. 'Permanent appointment without formality' is not a PSR category. (PSR 020202).

questions.question: What minimum percentage of all recruitments is reserved for persons with disability?
questions.explanation: PSR 020202(f) mandates that 5% of all recruitments in the Service be reserved for persons with disability. (PSR 020202).

questions.question: What is the standard probationary period for officers appointed on probation to pensionable establishment?
questions.explanation: PSR 020301 provides that officers on probation serve for two years before confirmation, subject to reductions in specific circumstances. (PSR 020301).

questions.question: During probation an officer must pass which of the following to be eligible for confirmation?
options: The prescribed examination appropriate to the appointment
A written testimonial from previous employer only
No requirement to pass any examination
questions.explanation: PSR 020302 requires that within probation an officer pass the prescribed examination appropriate to the appointment. (PSR 020302).

questions.question: Who is authorized, subject to delegation limits, to appoint eligible candidates to posts GL.06 and below?
options: Head of the Civil Service directly
questions.explanation: PSR 020101 states Permanent Secretaries/Heads of Extra-Ministerial Offices may appoint to posts where powers have been delegated — typically GL.06 and below. (PSR 020101).

questions.question: Which procedure is required for appointment to senior posts (GL.07 and above)?
options: Appointment by Federal Civil Service Commission after advertisement
Automatic promotion based on years of service
Selection by departmental head without advertisement
questions.explanation: PSR 020102 explains that FCSC appoints to GL.07–17 and such appointments are made into available vacancies after advertisement. (PSR 020102).

questions.question: Which form must applicants for senior posts complete as part of the FCSC process?
questions.explanation: PSR 020208(a) requires applicants for senior posts to complete the Federal Civil Service Commission Application Form (FC.2). (PSR 020208).

questions.question: When does the incremental date of an officer who was appointed or promoted become effective under PSR?
options: 1st January every year provided 6 months on grade with good performance
questions.explanation: PSR 020104 states the incremental date is 1 January provided the officer has spent at least six months on the grade with good performance. (PSR 020104).

questions.question: Which of the following must be submitted to the Office of the Head of the Civil Service, OAGF and PenCom within one month of appointment?
questions.explanation: PSR 020107 requires staff record form (Gen. 60) to be sent to OHCSF, OAGF, Auditor-General and PenCom within one month of appointment. (PSR 020107).

questions.question: Under PSR, membership of which type of organization by a public officer is prohibited?
questions.explanation: PSR 020211 prohibits public officers from being members of secret societies; contravention is serious misconduct. (PSR 020211).

questions.question: Under what condition may the normal two-year probation be reduced to not less than six months?
options: By deduction of previous satisfactory public service in cognate posts
If the officer is under 30 years old
questions.explanation: PSR 020301 allows reduction of probation to not less than six months by deduction of previous satisfactory public service in cognate posts. (PSR 020301).

questions.question: If an officer's probation is extended by the FCSC, what incremental consequence may the Commission impose?
questions.explanation: PSR 020301 states extensions may result in an incremental penalty as referred in Rule 040206. (PSR 020301; PSR 040206).

questions.question: Which examinations are senior posts required to pass while on probation?
options: COMPRO I & II as described in Chapter 3
questions.explanation: PSR 020302(a) states officers holding senior posts must pass the prescribed examinations described in Chapter 3 (COMPRO). (PSR 020302; Chapter 3).

questions.question: Which committee handles recruitment/selection for Junior Staff (GL.06 and below) in a Ministry?
questions.explanation: PSR 020103 states each Ministry shall appoint Junior Staff on GL.06 and below handled by the Junior Staff Committee. (PSR 020103).

questions.question: Which of the following is a condition for transfer/secondment to another service under PSR?
options: Officer must have been confirmed and qualifications align with Schemes of Service
Officer must be less than 30 years old
questions.explanation: PSR 020507(c) requires that an officer be confirmed and qualifications, experience and career progression are in accordance with the Schemes of Service for transfer/secondment. (PSR 020507).

questions.question: How long is an initial secondment to the service of another government, approved body or international organization allowed in the first instance?
questions.explanation: PSR 020505(f) states secondment to another government/approved body/international organization shall be for a maximum of two years in the first instance. (PSR 020505).

questions.question: If a secondment is in the public interest, what is the maximum total period allowed under PSR?
questions.explanation: PSR 020505(g) provides that if secondment is in public interest the period shall not exceed six years. (PSR 020505).

questions.question: During secondment, who continues to hold the officer's substantive post and entitlement to increment/promotion?
options: The officer continues to hold substantive post and is entitled to increment and promotion
questions.explanation: PSR 020505(h) says during secondment the officer continues to hold his substantive post and is entitled to increment and promotion. (PSR 020505).

questions.question: Which body must approve transfers/secondments of senior officers to parastatals under the supervision of a Ministry?
options: The Federal Civil Service Commission / Board
questions.explanation: PSR 020507(ii) mandates approval of the Federal Civil Service Commission/Board before transferring/seconding senior officers to parastatals under a Ministry. (PSR 020507).

questions.question: What periodic return must MDAs make concerning staff on transfer/secondment?
options: Quarterly returns to FCSC and OHCSF on number of staff on transfer/secondment
questions.explanation: PSR 020509 requires MDAs to make quarterly returns to the FCSC and OHCSF on number of staff on transfer/secondment. (PSR 020509).

questions.question: Which is the correct PSR rule that defines posting as the initial assignment or reassignment of an officer to a job schedule?
questions.explanation: PSR 020601 defines posting as initial assignment or reassignment of an officer to a position/job schedule. (PSR 020601).

questions.question: According to PSR, posting of officers to posts outside their professional cadre is:
questions.explanation: PSR 020602(ii) clearly states posting of officers to posts outside their professional cadres is prohibited. (PSR 020602).

questions.question: How often shall pool officers in the Service be mandatorily posted (as per PSR)?
questions.explanation: PSR 020602(iii) mandates that posting of pool officers is mandatory after every four (4) years. (PSR 020602).

questions.question: Failure of an officer to proceed on posting is regarded by PSR as:
questions.explanation: PSR 020602(iv) states failure to proceed on posting is regarded as misconduct. (PSR 020602).

questions.question: Acting appointments under PSR are:
options: Made only when necessary and are not a form of trial for promotion
Always for a minimum of 2 years
questions.explanation: PSR 020701 (section on Acting Appointment) indicates acting appointments are made when necessary and are not a form of trial for promotion. (PSR 020701).

questions.question: Which of the following is required before an officer can transfer-on-promotion to another MDA according to PSR?
options: Guarantee by the receiving Permanent Secretary
questions.explanation: PSR 020506 states no applicant shall be considered for transfer-on-promotion except in response to an advertised post. (PSR 020506).

questions.question: Which PSR rule requires that officers complete Personal Particulars Form Gen.60 immediately upon assuming duty?
questions.explanation: PSR 020209 (Personal Particulars) requires newly appointed officers to enter personal particulars on Form Gen.60 immediately upon assuming duty. (PSR 020209).

questions.question: Which rule directs that confirmation recommendations for officers holding senior posts should be made in the progress report prescribed in Chapter 5?
questions.explanation: PSR 020304 specifies that recommendations regarding confirmation of officers holding senior posts shall be made in the progress report prescribed in Chapter 5. (PSR 020304).

questions.question: Under PSR, can a confirmed officer who is advanced to a training grade be regarded as having been seconded?
options: Yes — treated as if seconded for the period of training
Only if training is outside Nigeria
questions.explanation: PSR 020204(b) states a confirmed officer advanced to training grade will be treated as if seconded thereto for the training period. (PSR 020204).

questions.question: Which rule prescribes that appointment to the National Youth Service Corps Presidential Merit Award winners is automatic regardless of vacancy?
questions.explanation: PSR 020202(i) (subparagraph in PSR 020202) states Ministries shall accept appointments made by FCSC to Presidential Merit Award winners whose employment is automatic regardless of vacancy constraints. (PSR 020202).

questions.question: Which PSR rule mandates that advertisement for FCSC vacancies appear in three national newspapers and the Commission's website with a six-week application deadline?
questions.explanation: PSR 020102(i) provides that FCSC advertisements for GL.07-17 vacancies be in three national newspapers and the Commission's website with a six-week deadline. (PSR 020102).

questions.question: Which PSR rule states that an officer must serve a minimum of six months in his original post before applying for transfer to another senior post?
questions.explanation: PSR 020307 specifies that an officer must have served a minimum of six months in his original post before seeking transfer to another post. (PSR 020307).

questions.question: For a transfer application under PSR 020307, which of the following must be included in the submission to FCSC?
options: Statement of applicant's performance, suitability and recommendation
questions.explanation: PSR 020307 requires the Permanent Secretary to forward application with statement on how applicant performed, suitability and recommendation. (PSR 020307).

questions.question: Which rule prohibits acceptance of staff seconded to an MDA without endorsement of the Federal Civil Service Commission/Board?
questions.explanation: PSR 020507(iii) prohibits any Ministry accepting staff seconded to it without endorsement of the Federal Civil Service Commission/Board. (PSR 020507).

questions.question: Which PSR rule mandates that a newly recruited officer who has spent six months and above shall be allowed to sit for compulsory examinations for confirmation?
questions.explanation: PSR 020306 permits newly recruited officers who have served six months and above to sit for compulsory confirmation examinations. (PSR 020306).

questions.question: Which Chapter contains detailed syllabuses and prescribed confirmation examinations (COMPRO) for senior executive and professional officers?
questions.explanation: Chapter 3 of the PSR contains prescribed examinations (COMPRO) and syllabuses for senior executive and professional officers. (Chapter 3; PSR 0302xx).

questions.question: Under PSR, which of these is TRUE about contract appointments?
options: They are temporary, non-pensionable and recorded in a formal agreement
They cannot be given to expatriates
questions.explanation: PSR 020402 defines contract appointments as temporary, non-pensionable and must be recorded in a formal document of agreement. (PSR 020402).

questions.question: Which of the following circumstances may warrant a contract appointment under PSR?
options: When a post can be filled internally immediately
Where service lacks officers with required specialized skills
questions.explanation: PSR 020403(i) permits contract appointments if the Service lacks officers with the required specialized skills as provided in approved Schemes of Service. (PSR 020403).

questions.question: Under PSR, who is responsible for appraising an officer who is seconded to another MDA?
options: The MDA to which the officer is seconded
questions.explanation: PSR 020507(iii) states an officer on secondment shall be appraised by the MDA to which he is seconded. (PSR 020507).

questions.question: Which rule explains that staff sent on secondment shall continue to be treated as holding their substantive post and paid by the benefiting organization while emoluments may be the responsibility of releasing MDA if differential exists?
questions.explanation: PSR 020505(h) & related paragraphs explain continuing substantive status and the allocation of payment responsibilities where salary differentials exist. (PSR 020505).

questions.question: Which PSR rule disqualifies appointment without prior specific approval where a candidate has been convicted of a criminal offence or dismissed from public service?
questions.explanation: PSR 020207(a) requires prior specific approval of FCSC or Board where candidate was convicted or previously dismissed from public service. (PSR 020207).

questions.question: Which PSR rule indicates that the date of birth recorded on appointment shall not be changed throughout an officer's career?
questions.explanation: PSR 020107(ii) prescribes the date of birth recorded on appointment shall not be changed and change is serious misconduct. (PSR 020107).

questions.question: Which PSR rule governs the withholding, deferring and restoration of increments (relates to incremental penalties)?
questions.explanation: PSR Chapter 4 (Rules 040206–040209) explains withholding/deferring increments and restoration, referenced in incremental penalties for probation extensions. (PSR 040206–040209).

questions.question: Under PSR, which body must be included as observers in Junior Staff and Senior Staff Committees in parastatals?
options: Representative of Department of Human Resource Management of supervising Ministry and an observer from OHCSF
questions.explanation: PSR 020305 & 170306 indicate JSC/SSC in parastatals shall include rep of HRM of supervising Ministry and an observer from OHCSF. (PSR 020305; PSR 170306).

questions.question: Which PSR rule sets the advertisement and selection linkage between FCSC and OHCSF for entry at GL.07–10?
options: PSR 020102(iv) combined with selection modalities prescribed by FCSC
questions.explanation: PSR 020102(iv) and its subsections prescribe annual competitive entry exam for GL.07–10 to be conducted by FCSC with OHCSF and training institutes. (PSR 020102).

questions.question: Under PSR, who may reduce the probationary period to less than two years (but not less than six months) by counting prior satisfactory public service?
options: The appointing authority subject to PSR provisions (e.g. FCSC)
questions.explanation: PSR 020301 allows reduction by deduction of previous satisfactory public service; such adjustments are administered by the appointing authority and subject to Commission rules. (PSR 020301).

questions.question: Which PSR rule governs that transfer from one senior post to another requires prior approval of the FCSC or appropriate board?
questions.explanation: PSR 020307 states transfer from one senior post to another requires prior approval of the FCSC or appropriate Board. (PSR 020307).

questions.question: Which PSR provision states that appointment documents and staff records must be typed/filled in ink and one copy sent to the National Record Centre and other offices?
questions.explanation: PSR 020107 requires Staff Record Form (Gen.60) to be completed in ink and copies sent to National Record Centre, OAGF, AGF and PenCom. (PSR 020107).

questions.question: Which PSR rule requires that in implementing postings, fairness must be ensured so posting is not used as a tool for coercion, punishment or cronyism?
questions.explanation: PSR 020603 states fairness is an underlying principle in postings to ensure the system is not used for coercion, punishment or cronyism. (PSR 020603).

subcategories.name: Discipline & Misconduct
subcategories.description: Covers misconduct, serious misconduct, disciplinary procedures, queries, interdiction, suspension, dismissal and appeals under Chapter 10 of the PSR 2021.

questions.question: Which of the following is classified as serious misconduct under the PSR?
options: Failure to submit reports on time
questions.explanation: According to PSR 100201, embezzlement of public funds constitutes serious misconduct and may lead to dismissal from service.

questions.question: Under PSR 2021, misconduct is defined as:
options: Any minor offence committed by a public officer
Any act of wrongdoing or improper behaviour inconsistent with the public service code
An act punishable by criminal law only
An offence that affects only senior officers
questions.explanation: PSR 100101 defines misconduct as a specific act of wrongdoing or improper behaviour inconsistent with the Public Service Code of Conduct and Ethics.

questions.question: Which of the following may amount to misconduct as per PSR?
questions.explanation: PSR 100202 lists neglect of duty as an example of misconduct for which disciplinary action may be taken.

questions.question: Serious misconduct shall lead to which disciplinary outcome?
questions.explanation: PSR 100201 provides that serious misconduct is a grave offence punishable by dismissal.

questions.question: Before any disciplinary action is taken against an officer, what must first be issued?
questions.explanation: PSR 100302 states that a query must be issued to an officer alleged to have committed misconduct before disciplinary action is taken.

questions.question: What is the time limit for an officer to reply a query under PSR?
options: 72 hours or as may be specified
questions.explanation: PSR 100302 requires an officer to reply a query within 72 hours or within a specified time in the query letter.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an example of serious misconduct?
options: Failure to submit annual leave application
questions.explanation: PSR 100201 lists dishonesty, falsification of records, and insubordination as serious misconduct, but failure to submit leave application is not classified as such.

questions.question: What is the first step in disciplinary proceedings for misconduct?
questions.explanation: According to PSR 100302, disciplinary proceedings begin with issuance of a query outlining the allegation to the officer.

questions.question: Who is responsible for initiating disciplinary action against a public officer?
options: Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office
questions.explanation: PSR 100303 assigns responsibility for initiating disciplinary action to the Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office.

questions.question: When an officer is under investigation for serious misconduct, what action may be taken to prevent interference?
questions.explanation: PSR 100305 allows for interdiction of an officer facing serious misconduct charges to prevent interference during investigation.

questions.question: During interdiction, what portion of an officer's salary is paid?
questions.explanation: PSR 100305 stipulates that an officer on interdiction shall be entitled to half of his salary pending the conclusion of investigation.

questions.question: Suspension of an officer is used when:
options: The officer refuses to attend training
A serious case involving public interest is under investigation
The officer is absent without leave
questions.explanation: PSR 100306 provides that suspension may be used where a serious case involving public interest is being investigated.

questions.question: For a case of misconduct, which committee recommends penalties to the Federal Civil Service Commission?
questions.explanation: PSR 100304 specifies that the Senior Staff Committee (Disciplinary) considers disciplinary cases and makes recommendations to the FCSC.

questions.question: When an officer is found guilty of misconduct but not dismissed, which punishment may be applied?
questions.explanation: PSR 100310 lists punishments such as reduction in rank, withholding increment, or written warning when misconduct does not warrant dismissal.

questions.question: An officer dismissed for serious misconduct loses all claims to:
options: Salary and benefits from date of dismissal
questions.explanation: PSR 100311 states that a dismissed officer forfeits all claims to remuneration and terminal benefits as from the date of dismissal.

questions.question: Where a disciplinary case has been pending for over six months without conclusion, the responsible authority must:
options: Submit a progress report to the Head of Service
questions.explanation: PSR 100309 requires that where a case remains pending beyond six months, a progress report must be submitted to the Head of Service.

questions.question: What punishment applies to an officer convicted by a court for a criminal offence involving dishonesty?
questions.explanation: PSR 100312 provides that an officer convicted of a criminal offence involving dishonesty shall be dismissed from service.

questions.question: Which PSR rule provides that disciplinary action shall not commence unless the officer has been informed in writing of the charges?
questions.explanation: PSR 100302 mandates written communication of allegations before disciplinary action begins.

questions.question: In cases involving fraud, falsification, or dishonesty, which agency must be notified?
options: Independent Corrupt Practices and Other Related Offences Commission (ICPC)
questions.explanation: PSR 100307 directs Ministries to notify ICPC or relevant anti-corruption agencies when cases involve fraud or dishonesty.

questions.question: When is an officer deemed to have abandoned duty under PSR?
options: After 10 consecutive working days without permission
questions.explanation: PSR 100308 considers an officer absent without leave for 10 working days as having abandoned duty and liable to dismissal.

questions.question: What happens when an officer under interdiction is found not guilty of the offence?
options: The interdiction remains for record purposes
He is reinstated and unpaid salary refunded
The case file is closed without reinstatement
questions.explanation: PSR 100305 states that if the officer is exonerated, he must be reinstated and the balance of salary refunded.

questions.question: Under PSR 2021, which action may be taken against an officer found guilty of misconduct but whose offence is not grave enough for dismissal?
options: Written warning or deferment of increment
questions.explanation: PSR 100310 provides that lesser punishments such as written warning, deferment or withholding of increment, or reduction in rank may apply.

questions.question: Which PSR provision ensures an officer is given a fair hearing before any disciplinary action is taken?
questions.explanation: PSR 100303 guarantees an officer the right to a fair hearing consistent with Section 36 of the Constitution before disciplinary action.

questions.question: When an officer is suspended, what proportion of salary is paid?
questions.explanation: PSR 100306 states that suspension is normally without pay during the period of investigation for serious offences.

questions.question: If an officer under suspension is acquitted, what should happen?
options: Officer is reinstated and full salary restored
questions.explanation: PSR 100306(b) requires reinstatement and full payment of withheld emoluments if the officer is acquitted.

questions.question: Under PSR, termination differs from dismissal because:
options: Termination allows payment of benefits while dismissal forfeits them
questions.explanation: PSR 100311 distinguishes termination (with benefits) from dismissal (forfeiture of benefits and disqualification from re-employment).

questions.question: Which disciplinary measure can be imposed for persistent lateness or negligence not amounting to serious misconduct?
questions.explanation: PSR 100310 lists written warning as appropriate for minor cases of negligence or inefficiency.

questions.question: An officer may be dismissed without further disciplinary proceedings if:
options: He is convicted by a court of law
He receives three queries in a year
questions.explanation: PSR 100312 allows dismissal without further proceedings after a criminal conviction involving dishonesty or moral turpitude.

questions.question: Under PSR, who approves dismissal for officers on GL.07 and above?
questions.explanation: PSR 100303 and 100304 designate the Federal Civil Service Commission as the approving authority for dismissal of senior officers.

questions.question: Which committee handles disciplinary cases involving officers on GL.06 and below?
questions.explanation: PSR 100304 provides that the Junior Staff Committee (Disciplinary) handles disciplinary cases for officers on GL.06 and below.

questions.question: How many days must elapse before an officer absent without leave is assumed to have abandoned duty?
questions.explanation: PSR 100308 specifies that an officer absent for 10 consecutive working days without permission is deemed to have abandoned duty.

questions.question: Which PSR rule allows the use of video or electronic evidence in disciplinary proceedings?
questions.explanation: PSR 100315 introduces acceptance of electronic and video evidence in line with modern administrative justice standards.

questions.question: Which rule empowers the Head of Service to direct reinstatement after an officer is cleared on appeal?
questions.explanation: PSR 100316 gives the Head of Service power to direct reinstatement after successful appeal or exoneration.

questions.question: What should happen to an officer's record after dismissal?
questions.explanation: PSR 100311(c) mandates that dismissed officers' records be marked accordingly and kept for administrative reference.

questions.question: An officer under interdiction who takes up private employment before conclusion of his case commits:
questions.explanation: PSR 100305(e) forbids taking up private employment while under interdiction; such act constitutes serious misconduct.

questions.question: Where a disciplinary decision is made in error or without due process, the PSR provides that:
options: The FCSC may review and reverse it
The Head of Service must approve it
questions.explanation: PSR 100316 permits the FCSC to review and reverse any disciplinary decision made in error or without due process.

questions.question: What is the responsibility of Permanent Secretaries after disciplinary proceedings have been concluded?
options: Forward copies of decisions to OHCSF and FCSC
questions.explanation: PSR 100314 mandates submission of disciplinary outcomes to OHCSF and FCSC for record and oversight.

questions.question: Which PSR rule addresses the disciplinary process in parastatals and agencies?
questions.explanation: PSR 170305 aligns parastatal disciplinary procedure with Chapter 10 of PSR, requiring Board oversight and OHCSF notification.

questions.question: If a dismissed officer later wins an appeal, which right is restored under PSR?
options: All rights, emoluments, and benefits as if never dismissed
questions.explanation: PSR 100316(b) provides that on successful appeal, the officer is entitled to all rights and benefits as if never dismissed.

questions.question: A disciplinary case against a deceased officer should be:
questions.explanation: PSR 100309(c) directs that disciplinary proceedings terminate upon the death of the officer.

questions.question: If a disciplinary case leads to dismissal and the officer appeals unsuccessfully, can he be re-employed?
options: Only with approval of the Federal Civil Service Commission
questions.explanation: PSR 100316(d) permits re-employment of a dismissed officer only upon FCSC approval.

questions.question: An officer on trial in court must be placed on what status pending judgment?
options: Suspension or interdiction depending on gravity
questions.explanation: PSR 100305 and 100306 provide for interdiction or suspension pending court outcome depending on offence severity.

questions.question: If an officer under investigation absconds, what disciplinary action applies?
options: Salary is stopped but investigation continues
questions.explanation: PSR 100308 provides that absence without permission or abscondment equals desertion, leading to dismissal.

questions.question: What must accompany all disciplinary proceedings records forwarded to the Commission?
options: A full set of evidence, minutes and recommendation
questions.explanation: PSR 100314 requires that disciplinary records forwarded to FCSC must include evidence, minutes and recommendations.

questions.question: When a disciplinary case involves financial loss to Government, the amount is:
options: Recovered from officer where culpability is proven
questions.explanation: PSR 100307(b) directs recovery of any financial loss caused by an officer found culpable after disciplinary proceedings.

questions.question: Under PSR, which penalty results in forfeiture of all pension and gratuity rights?
questions.explanation: PSR 100311(c) explicitly states dismissal results in forfeiture of all claims to terminal benefits.

questions.question: An officer who falsifies his age at entry into service commits:
questions.explanation: PSR 100201(f) classifies falsification of records, including age, as serious misconduct punishable by dismissal.

questions.question: What is the purpose of maintaining disciplinary registers in Ministries?
options: To record staff disciplinary outcomes for reference and audit
questions.explanation: PSR 100314 requires Ministries to maintain disciplinary registers for record, monitoring and audit purposes.

questions.question: Under PSR, which of the following may not appeal a disciplinary decision?
questions.explanation: PSR 100316(a) allows appeals only by living officers; proceedings terminate upon death of the officer.

questions.question: Under PSR 2021, what is the maximum timeline within which the Federal Civil Service Commission should conclude disciplinary cases referred to it?
questions.explanation: PSR 100309(b) provides that FCSC should ensure disciplinary cases are concluded within six months from commencement.

subcategories.name: Leave, Absence & Holidays
subcategories.description: Covers types of leave, eligibility, computation, approval authority, and related conditions under PSR 2021 Chapter 12.

questions.question: What is the minimum annual leave entitlement for officers on Grade Level 07 and above according to PSR 2021?
questions.explanation: PSR 120101 provides that officers on GL.07 and above are entitled to 28 working days annual leave in each leave year.

questions.question: How many working days of annual leave are officers on GL.06 and below entitled to?
questions.explanation: PSR 120101 specifies that officers on GL.06 and below are entitled to 21 working days annual leave each year.

questions.question: Leave year in the Federal Public Service is defined as:
questions.explanation: PSR 120102 defines the leave year as beginning on 1st January and ending on 31st December each year.

questions.question: Which PSR provision governs leave entitlement for officers who have not completed 12 months of continuous service?
questions.explanation: PSR 120104 states that officers who have not completed 12 months continuous service are entitled to leave proportionate to service rendered.

questions.question: How many days of annual leave may be deferred to the next leave year with proper approval?
questions.explanation: PSR 120105 allows a maximum of 14 days to be deferred to the next leave year with appropriate approval.

questions.question: What is the minimum qualifying service before an officer can proceed on annual leave?
questions.explanation: PSR 120103 requires an officer to complete a minimum of 12 months of continuous service before becoming eligible for annual leave.

questions.question: Which authority may approve annual leave for officers on GL.13 and above?
options: Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office
questions.explanation: PSR 120107 states that annual leave for officers on GL.13 and above shall be approved by the Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office.

questions.question: Officers who cannot be spared during the leave year may be granted how many days leave in lieu with monetary compensation?
questions.explanation: PSR 120106 allows officers who cannot be spared to take up to 14 days leave in lieu, with leave allowance paid in addition.

questions.question: How is annual leave calculated in PSR 2021?
options: On a monthly basis at 1/12th per month of service
questions.explanation: PSR 120104 provides that annual leave accrues monthly at the rate of one-twelfth of the total annual entitlement.

questions.question: What is the leave allowance percentage payable on annual basic salary?
questions.explanation: PSR 120108 provides that leave allowance is 10% of annual basic salary, payable once a year to every officer proceeding on leave.

questions.question: What is the duration of maternity leave under PSR 2021?
questions.explanation: PSR 120201 states that female officers are entitled to 16 weeks maternity leave with full pay.

questions.question: When does maternity leave normally commence?
options: At least 4 weeks before the expected date of delivery
questions.explanation: PSR 120201 provides that maternity leave begins 4 weeks before the expected date of delivery.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of maternity leaves a female officer can enjoy in her career?
questions.explanation: PSR 120201(b) limits maternity leave to a maximum of four times during an officer's career.

questions.question: What is the duration of paternity leave approved under PSR 2021?
questions.explanation: PSR 120202 provides that male officers are entitled to 10 working days paternity leave after the birth of a child.

questions.question: How many days of casual leave may an officer be granted per year?
questions.explanation: PSR 120109 allows up to 10 working days of casual leave per year, not deductible from annual leave.

questions.question: Which PSR rule provides for study leave with pay for officers undergoing approved courses relevant to their duties?
questions.explanation: PSR 120207 grants study leave with pay for approved courses relevant to the officer's duties and beneficial to the Service.

questions.question: What is the maximum period for study leave with pay under PSR?
questions.explanation: PSR 120207(b) provides that study leave with pay shall not exceed 36 months at a stretch.

questions.question: Who must approve study leave with pay exceeding one year?
options: Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office with FCSC approval
questions.explanation: PSR 120207(c) requires FCSC approval for study leave with pay exceeding one year.

questions.question: What is the consequence of failing to resume duty after expiration of approved leave?
options: Loss of pay for excess days and possible disciplinary action
questions.explanation: PSR 120110 provides that failure to resume after leave results in loss of pay for the period and may attract disciplinary action.

questions.question: How many months of sick leave with full pay are officers entitled to within any 12-month period?
questions.explanation: PSR 120203(a) provides six months sick leave with full pay within a 12-month period, extendable under medical advice.

questions.question: What follows after six months of sick leave with full pay if the officer is still unfit?
options: Sick leave with half pay for further six months
questions.explanation: PSR 120203(b) allows an extension of six months with half pay if the officer remains unfit after the initial six months.

questions.question: What authority must certify an officer's illness before granting sick leave exceeding two days?
questions.explanation: PSR 120203(c) requires certification by a Government Medical Officer for sick leave beyond two working days.

questions.question: Which PSR rule provides for pre-retirement leave?
questions.explanation: PSR 120211 grants pre-retirement leave of three months to officers retiring voluntarily or compulsorily.

questions.question: Public holidays in the Federal Service are declared by which authority?
options: The President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria
questions.explanation: PSR 120209 provides that public holidays are declared by the President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria.

questions.question: Officers who are hospitalized while on annual leave are entitled to:
options: Conversion of the affected period to sick leave
questions.explanation: PSR 120203(e) provides that hospitalization during leave converts the affected period to sick leave upon certification.

questions.question: Under PSR 2021, how many times may an officer be granted study leave without pay?
questions.explanation: PSR 120208 restricts study leave without pay to once during an officer's career, unless otherwise approved by the Federal Civil Service Commission.

questions.question: How long must an officer serve after returning from study leave with pay before applying for another?
questions.explanation: PSR 120207(e) requires an officer to serve at least three years after resumption before being eligible for another study leave with pay.

questions.question: An officer who fails to resume duty after study leave without valid reason shall be treated as:
options: To have resigned from the service
questions.explanation: PSR 120208(b) provides that failure to resume after study leave without valid reason is deemed resignation from the Service.

questions.question: Which rule specifies the treatment of unauthorized absence from duty?
questions.explanation: PSR 100308 (linked to Chapter 10) states that unauthorized absence for 10 consecutive working days constitutes abandonment of duty.

questions.question: What is the maximum period for leave on compassionate grounds under PSR?
questions.explanation: PSR 120205 provides that compassionate leave not exceeding 14 working days may be granted in deserving cases.

questions.question: Who approves sick leave exceeding 42 days?
options: Permanent Secretary on advice of a Government Medical Board
questions.explanation: PSR 120203(d) requires approval of the Permanent Secretary based on recommendation from a Government Medical Board for sick leave exceeding 42 days.

questions.question: What should be done when a public holiday falls within an officer's approved annual leave period?
options: The day is added to the leave period
The day counts as part of the leave
Officer must report for duty on the holiday
questions.explanation: PSR 120209(b) provides that public holidays occurring during annual leave count as part of the leave.

questions.question: Officers on what category of leave are not entitled to leave allowance?
questions.explanation: PSR 120207(f) stipulates that officers on study leave with pay are not entitled to leave allowance during the period.

questions.question: How many consecutive years may an officer defer annual leave before it is forfeited?
questions.explanation: PSR 120105 allows deferment of leave for only one subsequent year; thereafter, unused leave is forfeited.

questions.question: Under PSR 2021, officers on GL.14 and above must obtain whose approval to travel abroad while on leave?
options: Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: PSR 120107(c) requires officers on GL.14 and above to obtain clearance from the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation before travelling abroad while on leave.

questions.question: An officer on approved study leave with pay who withdraws from the course without permission shall:
options: Refund emoluments received during the leave
questions.explanation: PSR 120207(g) requires refund of all emoluments by any officer who withdraws from an approved course without authorization.

questions.question: During pre-retirement leave, the officer is entitled to:
questions.explanation: PSR 120211(b) provides that pre-retirement leave is with full pay and benefits.

questions.question: What is the main difference between study leave with pay and without pay?
questions.explanation: PSR 120207 and 120208 distinguish between study leave with pay (for relevant approved courses) and without pay (for unrelated or self-sponsored study).

questions.question: Who approves compassionate leave beyond 14 days?
options: Permanent Secretary or Head of Extra-Ministerial Office
Head of the Civil Service of the Federation
questions.explanation: PSR 120205(b) provides that compassionate leave exceeding 14 days requires approval of the Head of the Civil Service of the Federation.

questions.question: Which PSR provision deals with leave for officers posted to missions abroad?
questions.explanation: PSR 130206 governs leave for officers serving in Nigeria's missions abroad, applied in conjunction with Chapter 12.

questions.question: What should be attached to leave applications according to PSR?
options: Leave roster and duty relief arrangement
questions.explanation: PSR 120107(d) requires officers to attach leave roster and duty relief arrangements to their leave applications.

questions.question: An officer who over-stays approved leave without permission commits:
questions.explanation: PSR 120110 treats over-staying leave as serious misconduct punishable under disciplinary rules.

questions.question: Can a nursing mother combine maternity leave with annual leave?
options: Yes, with approval of Permanent Secretary
No, maternity leave must be taken separately
questions.explanation: PSR 120201(c) allows maternity leave to be combined with annual leave upon approval by the Permanent Secretary.

questions.question: If a public holiday is declared during pre-retirement leave, the officer:
options: Remains on leave as the day counts within it
Returns to duty for the holiday
questions.explanation: PSR 120209 clarifies that public holidays falling during any form of leave, including pre-retirement, count within the leave period.

questions.question: What is the consequence for an officer who overstays study leave without approval?
options: Deemed to have resigned from the Service
questions.explanation: PSR 120208(c) provides that overstay beyond approved study leave period without approval is treated as resignation.

questions.question: Officers granted paternity leave must apply within what period after the birth of a child?
questions.explanation: PSR 120202 provides that paternity leave applications must be made within 14 days of the child's birth.

subcategories.name: Allowances, Pay & Benefits
subcategories.description: Covers the rules on allowances, salary payment, acting appointment benefits, responsibility allowance, transport, overtime, and advances as provided in PSR 2021 Chapters 13–14.

questions.question: What PSR provision governs payment of duty tour allowance?
questions.explanation: PSR 130101 defines duty tour allowance as payment to cover expenses incurred by an officer on official assignment away from duty station.
